page.title: 4.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will further develop your ability to describe the characteristics of graphs. You will use mathematical terms such as intercept, maximum, and minimum in your graphical analyses, and you will relate features of graphs to features of the functions represented.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Identify important features of graphs of functions and explain what they mean in the situations represented.
  • Explain and apply the terms “horizontal intercept,” “vertical intercept,” “maximum,” and “minimum” when talking about functions and their graphs.
  • Identify important features of linear functions.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.6.1: Interpreting Statements in Function Notation
  • 4.6.2: Analyzing Graphs of Functions
  • 4.6.2: Self Check
  • 4.6.3: Connecting Graphical and Verbal Representations of a Function
  • 4.6.3: Self Check
  • 4.6.4: Key Features of Linear Functions
  • 4.6.5: Interpreting Graphs

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.6.6: Practice
  • 4.6.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 4.6.1: Interpreting Statements in Function Notation
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Diego is walking home from school at a constant rate. This graph represents function \(d\), which gives his distance from home, in kilometers, \(m\) minutes since leaving the school.

Use the graph to find or estimate:


  1. What is \(d(0)\), and what does it represent in the situation? Enter your answer here:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(d(0)=2.25\); Zero minutes after Diego has left school, he is 2.25 kilometers from home, or Diego’s school is a little more than 2 kilometers from his house.



  1. \(d(12) =\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(d(12)=0.9\)



  1. What does \(d(m)=1\) mean in the context of the problem, and what is \(m\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(m\) is approximately 10.5. After approximately 10.5 minutes, Diego is 1 kilometer from home.



  1. What does \(d(m)=0\) mean in the context of the problem, and what is \(m\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(m\) is 20. After 20 minutes, Diego is 0 kilometers from home, or it takes Diego 20 minutes to walk the 2.25 kilometers home from school.

page.title: 4.6.2: Analyzing Graphs of Functions
page.contents:
Activity

A toy rocket and a drone were launched at the same time.

Here are the graphs that represent the heights of two objects as a function of time since they were launched.

Height is measured in meters above the ground, and time is measured in seconds since launch.


  1. Analyze the graph of the toy rocket and describe as precisely as you can what was happening. Your description should be complete and precise enough that someone who is not looking at the graph could visualize how the object was behaving. Include where the toy rocket starts and when it stops. Enter your answer here:

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The toy rocket was launched from a height of 25 meters above ground. It went up quickly, but it slowed down and then stopped getting higher when it reached 45 meters, which was 2 seconds after launch. At that point, it started to come back down. It hit the ground 5 seconds after it was launched.



  1. Analyze the graph of the drone and describe as precisely as you can what was happening. Your description should be complete and precise enough that someone who is not looking at the graph could visualize how the object was behaving. Include where the drone starts and when it stops.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The drone took off from the ground. It went up at a constant speed for 2 seconds, up to a height of 20 meters. Then, it hovered at that height for 3 seconds. Afterward, it started descending at a constant speed for 2 seconds. It landed back on the ground 7 seconds after launch.



  1. At what point were the drone and the toy rocket at the same height?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

A little after 4 seconds, the drone and the toy rocket were at the same height (20 meters).



  1. Which parts or features of the graphs show important information about each object’s movement? List the features or mark them on the graphs.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  • the points where the graphs begin (when \(t\) is 0)
  • the points where the graphs cross the horizontal axis
  • the point where the graphs change direction
  • the shape of each graph (curved or straight)
  • the intervals when the graphs behave certain ways
  • the parts highlighted in the graph

page.title: 4.6.2: Self Check
page.contents: The graph below represents the temperature, \(t(m)\), in degrees Fahrenheit of water used for a cup of hot tea over time in minutes, \(m\). What does \(t(0)\) represent?

answer.answer_text: \(t(0)=70\); After 70 minutes, the temperature is 0 degrees.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember the value inside the parentheses is the minutes passed, so \(t(0)\) means 0 minutes have passed. The answer is \(t(0)=70\); After 0 minutes, the temperature is 70 degrees.

answer.answer_text: \(t(0)=180\); After 0 minutes, the temperature is 180 degrees.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: On the graph provided, the graph intersects the vertical axis at 70, not 180. The answer is \(t(0)=70\); After 0 minutes, the temperature is 70 degrees.

answer.answer_text: \(t(0)=70\); After 0 minutes, the temperature is 70 degrees.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: \(t(0)= 70\) means that the \(x\) value is 0, or it is the point on the vertical axis. The point where the graph intersects the vertical axis is 70 degrees.

answer.answer_text: \(t(0)= 180\); After 180 minutes, the temperature is 0 degrees.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember the value inside the parentheses is the minutes passed, so \(t(0)\) means 0 minutes have passed. The answer is \(t(0)=70\); At 0 minutes, the temperature is 70 degrees.

page.title: 4.6.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Real-Life Graphs of Functions

A ball is bouncing across the school yard. The vertical or \(y\)-axis represents the height of the ball in feet, \(h(t)\), while the horizontal or \(x\)-axis represents the time, \(t\), that has passed in seconds. 



On the graph, \(t=0\) represents the first time the ball touches the ground.

What is \(h(1)\), and what does it represent in the context of the problem?

\(h(1) = 0\), and it represents the height of the ball after 1 second, or the ball has a height of zero after 1 second. The value inside of the parentheses is the value from the \(x\)-axis or horizontal axis. The solution is the value of the graph at that point.

Try It: Real-Life Graphs of Functions

A ball is thrown across the field from point \(A\) to point \(B\). It hits the ground at point \(B\). The path of the ball is shown in the diagram below. The \(x\)-axis shows the horizontal distance the ball travels in feet, and the \(y\)-axis shows the height of the ball in feet.

Explain what \(f(C)\) means in this graph.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to explain \(f(C)\) in the graph:

\(f(C)\) tells you to look at the height of the graph when \(x=C\).

This point on the graph is the highest point, or maximum.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.6.3: Connecting Graphical and Verbal Representations of a Function
page.contents:
Activity

In a bungee jump, the height of the jumper is a function of time since the jump begins.

Function \(h\) defines the height, in meters, of a jumper above a river, \(t\) seconds since leaving the platform.

Here is a graph of function \(h\), followed by five expressions or equations and five graphical features.

Expressions and Equations

\(h(0)\)

\(h(t)=0\)

\(h(4)\)

\(h(t)=80\)

\(h(t)=45\)

Features

  • first dip in the graph
  • vertical intercept
  • first peak in the graph
  • horizontal intercept
  • maximum
  1. Match each description about the jump to a corresponding expression or equation and to a feature on the graph.

One expression or equation does not have a matching verbal description. Its corresponding graphical feature is also not shown on the graph. Interpret that expression or equation in terms of the jump and in terms of the graph of the function. Record your interpretation in the last row of the table.

Description of Jump

Expression or Equation

Feature of Graph
  1. the greatest height that the jumper is from the river
    
  1. the height from which the jumper was jumping
    
  1. the time at which the jumper reached the highest point after the first bounce
    
  1. the lowest point that the jumper reached in the entire jump
    

  1. Expression or Equation

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(t)=80\)



Feature of Graph

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

maximum



  1. Expression or Equation

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(0)\)



Feature of Graph

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

vertical intercept



  1. Expression or Equation

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(t)=45\)



Feature of Graph

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

first peak in the graph



  1. Expression or Equation

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(4)\)



Feature of Graph

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

first dip in the graph; also the minimum of the graph shown



  1. Description of Jump

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

the time at which the jumper hits the surface of the river



Expression or Equation

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(t)=0\)



Feature of Graph

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

horizontal intercept



Use the graph to:

  1. estimate \(h(0)\) and \(h(4)\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(h(0)\) is 80, and \(h(4)\) is about 10.



  1. estimate the solutions to \(h(t)=45\) and \(h(t)=0\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

There is no solution to \(h(t)=0\) when \(t\) is between 0 and 35, which is what is shown on the graph. We don’t know if it will have a solution when \(t\) is greater than 35.


Video: The Meaning of Function Notation

Watch the following video to learn more about connecting graphical and verbal representations of a function.



The horizontal intercept is also called the \(x\)-intercept, or zero.

The vertical intercept is also called the \(y\)-intercept.


Extending Your Thinking

Based on the information available, how long do you think the bungee cord is? Make an estimate and explain your reasoning.

Write your answer here:

Compare your answers:

About 50 meters. The low points on the graph increase with each bounce, and the high points decrease. They look like they are approaching about 30 meters in height above the river. Since the jump started from 80 meters above the river, this means that the bungee cord is about 50 meters long.

page.title: 4.6.3: Self Check
page.contents: The graph models the height, in feet, of a kickball over time. When is the ball at its maximum height?

answer.answer_text: \(h(2.5) = 31\); The maximum height is about 31 feet. It occurred about 2.5 seconds after the ball was kicked.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Maximums are the highest points on the graph. The maximum of this graph is \(h(2.5)=31\).

answer.answer_text: \(h(5)=0\); The maximum height occurs about 6 seconds after the ball was kicked.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \(h(5)=0\) represents the point when the ball returns to the ground, or the horizontal axis intercept. The answer is the maximum of this graph is \(h(2.5)=31\).

answer.answer_text: \(h(1)=20\); The maximum height occurred 1 second after the ball was kicked.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The maximum is the highest point on the graph. \(h(1)=20\) is not the highest point. The answer is \(h(2.5)=31\). The maximum of this graph is 31.

answer.answer_text: \(h(2.5) = 31\); The maximum height is about 2.5 feet. It occurred about 31 seconds after the ball was kicked.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The maximum is the highest value on the vertical axis. \(h(2.5)=31\) is the correct answer, but the 2.5 represents the time, and 31 represents the height. The answer is the maximum is about 31 feet, and it occurred after 2.5 seconds.

page.title: 4.6.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
More Real-Life Graphs

The graph below represents the total number of smartphones that are shipped to a retail store over the course of 50 days.

Why does \(f(20) = f(22)\)?

Since section B is not changing, it represents the period of time where the store did not receive new shipments, so \(f(20)=f(22)\).

Try It: More Real-Life Graphs

The relationship between Jameson’s account balance \(B\), in dollars, and time \(t\), in days, is modeled by the graph below.

What does the point \(B(9)=100\) represent in the context of the problem?

In your notebook, write your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to describe what \(B(9)=100\) represents in the context of the problem:

\(B(9)=100\) represents the maximum amount of money Jameson had in his account over the time period shown. It also represents that after 9 days, Jameson had $100 in his account. It is the maximum because it is the highest point on the graph provided.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.6.4: Key Features of Linear Functions
page.contents:
Activity

  1. The graph of \(f(x)=2x+6\) is graphed below. Answer the questions about the linear function and its key features.


  1. What is the value of \(f(-3)\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

0



  1. What key feature of the linear function is the point \((-3,0)\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(x\)-intercept, or zero



  1. What is the slope of the linear function?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

2



  1. What part of the linear function is the point \((0, 6)\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The y-intercept


  1. The amount of money Adam saves in dollars is shown in the graph here:


  1. What is the \(y\)-intercept of the graph, and what does it mean in the context of the problem?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The point is \((0,3)\). When Adam started saving, he already had 3 dollars on day 0.



  1. What is the slope, and what does it mean in the context of the problem?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The slope is 3. Every 1 day, Adam saves 3 dollars.

page.title: 4.6.4: Self Check
page.contents: What is the zero of the linear function graphed below?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The zero is where the function crosses the \(x\)-axis.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the \(y\)-intercept. The zero is located where the function value is zero, at the \(x\)-intercept. The answer is \((6,0)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(x\)-coordinate is the first value in the ordered pair, and the \(y\)-coordinate is the second value. The answer is \((6,0)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the origin, but it is not a point on the graph of this linear function. The answer is \((6,0)\).

page.title: 4.6.4 Additional Resources
page.contents:
Features of Linear Functions

The graph of a linear function forms a line that goes on forever in both directions. Since the ends go to infinity and negative infinity, linear functions do not have maximums or minimums, unless their domain is restricted to a specific part of the graph.

You can still pick out key features of linear functions.

The \(x\)-intercept, or zero, is where the line crosses the \(x\)-axis. This is where the \(y\)-coordinate is 0.

In this linear function, the \(x\)-intercept, or zero, is \(x= 2\) and written as the point \((2,0)\).

The \(y\)-intercept is where the line crosses the \(y\)-axis and the \(x\)-coordinate is 0.

In this linear function, the \(y\)-intercept is \(y=4\) and written as the point \((0,4)\).

The slope of the line can be found as in previous units as the change in \(y\) over the change in \(x\).

\(\mathrm m=\;\frac{\mathrm{rise}}{\mathrm{run}}=\;\frac{\mathrm{change}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm y}{\mathrm{change}\;\mathrm{in}\;\mathrm x}\).

The slope of this linear function is \(m=4-2=-2\).

Try It: Features of Linear Functions

Find the \(x\)-intercept and \(y\)-intercept of the linear function graphed below. Write each answer as a point.


In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the intercepts of a linear function:

Since the line crosses the \(x\)-axis at about \((-2.75, 0)\), that is the \(x\)-intercept.

Since the line crosses the \(y\)-axis at \((0,2)\), that is the \(y\)-intercept.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.6.5: Interpreting Graphs
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A squirrel runs up and down a tree.

The graph shows the height of the squirrel, \(h\) (feet), as a function of time, \(t\) (seconds).


  1. What is the highest point the squirrel reaches?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

14 feet



  1. Solve \(h(t)=0\). What does this solution tell you about the squirrel?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(t=4\) means that after 4 seconds, the squirrel is at the bottom of the tree on the ground.



  1. Find the vertical intercept of the graph. What does it tell you about the squirrel?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((0,9)\) means that at the beginning, the squirrel is 9 feet high in the tree.

page.title: 4.6.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. This graph represents Andre’s distance from his bicycle as he walks in a park.


Decide whether the following statements are true or false.

  1. The graph has multiple horizontal intercepts.

Correct! True

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activit ies 4.6.2-4.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is True. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A horizontal intercept of the graph represents the time when Andre was with his bike.

Correct! True

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.6.2-4.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is True. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A maximum of the graph is the point (17,1)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.6.2-4.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is false. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph represents the temperature, in degrees Fahrenheit, as a function of time. 

 

At what hour in the afternoon does the maximum of the graph occur? Insert integers only.

Correct! 3 p.m.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 3 p.m. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Match each feature of the situation with a corresponding statement in function notation.

    1. \(h(0)= 7\)

Correct! Starting height

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Starting height. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(h(1.5)\)

Correct! Minimum height

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Minimum height. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(h(4)\)

Correct! Maximum height

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Maximum height. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \(h(t)=6\) for \(7 ≤t ≤8\)

Correct! Height staying the same

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.6.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Height staying the same. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph of \(f(x) =x^2\) is provided.

    1. What is \(f(2)\)?

      Enter Answer Here: Enter Only Integers

Correct!  The value of \(f(x)\) when x is 2 or \(f(2) = 4\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 4.6.2-4.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the value of \(f(x)\) when \(x\) is 2 or \(f(2) = 4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(f(1)\)?

      Enter Answer Here: Enter Only Integers

Correct! f(1) = 1

Try again.Why don't you go back to activities 4.6.2-4.6.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(1) = 1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Shannon is running on a flat, rocky trail that eventually rises up a steep mountain. The graph below represents the total distance she covers with respect to time.

    2. How many miles does Shannon run in 60 minutes? 

    Enter Answer Here: Enter Only Integers

Correct! 3 miles

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.6.2-4.6.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3 miles. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.6.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Identify important features of graphs of functions and explain what they mean in the situations represented.
  • Explain and apply the terms “horizontal intercept,” “vertical intercept,” “maximum,” and “minimum” when talking about functions and their graphs.
  • Identify important features of linear functions.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.6.1: Interpreting Statements in Function Notation
    • In this activity, you interpreted function notation using a graph. You completed mathematical statements and found the value of variables by reading the information from a graph.
  • 4.6.2: Analyzing Graphs of Functions
    • In this activity, you looked at the graphs of two different real-life functions. You identified key features such as minimum and maximum, \(x\)-intercepts and \(y\)-intercepts, and what they mean in a real-life situation.
  • 4.6.2: Self Check
  • 4.6.3: Connecting Graphical and Verbal Representations of a Function
    • In this activity, you continued working with graphs, function notation, and real-life situations. You interpreted statements about a real-life graph and connected them to the function notation that represented them.
  • 4.6.3: Self Check
  • 4.6.4: Key Features of Linear Functions
    • In this activity, you recognized the \(x\)-intercepts, zeros, slope, and \(y\)-intercepts of linear functions.
  • 4.6.4: Self Check
  • 4.6.5: Interpreting Graphs
    • In this activity, you examined specific points and key features on the graph and interpreted their meaning verbally and algebraically.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.6.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
